content:
there are no testcases starting with 9
or starting with x and all digits above x being used

but there is a validator like that

shame on the approvers...
This contribution hasnâ€™t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.
I'm getting the feeling that most clashers will not be able to solve this one in reverse mode. Why not settle for fastest and shortest?
I hope, I will remember the problem when it comes to a reverse clash... :'D
In c++ at least, test 6 requires me to put a newline at the end of the output while the rest does not, not sure what that is about though.
Thank you. I have now checked all the tests and validators for these kinds of mistakes.

I agree, this is one of the tougher reverse clashes. ;)

But it should be manageable I guess.

There are many others that are pretty hard, too.
And the hardness is pretty subjective because one's mindset affects how quickly one figures out the rule.
It was still accepted.
I ammended the test cases and validators.

Hi, just came from a reverse clash and this was hard. Now looking at the statement I feel like I should have seen that none of the input numbers are in the output.
There were 3 things I was (too) focused about while doing this:
* Input and output have the same length. If there was a case where this wasn't a possibility, it might help (like `911` -> `2000`)
* The second+ digit is always the first%2 for all test cases except 9: `82222` but still all digits were even. I thought this was a major part of the statement
* The first digit is always 1 more then the first digit of the input. Except for `56` -> `70` which just happend to map a multiple of 7 (and 14) to another one. This one is mostly on me though.

In the end i went with something that worked for 8/10 of the test cases (the 2 above mentioned not)
Link to clash: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/579e8731c9868f98614ed6d60ea275f1ba7
